commentBody: Fun puzzle. A bit challenging for a Tuesday and I liked that. Clever theme too.
Really clever!
I've struggled the past two nights. 6 minutes and 11 minutes. Not sure if I'm just jet lagged or they're actually trickier than usual. 4 and 6 are my usual solve time for Monday and Tuesday

Hedgerow made me think of WWII France.
Maybe I'm just getting  too old...
I felt that this dinkum was very fair. Probably the fairest dinkum I've ever encountered.
Nice one!

This was a perfect Tuesday grid. I liked the theme today. This must have been very challenging to construct. WAHWAH may be the sound of the sad trombone, but it also reminds me of Peter Frampton and his wahwah pedal üòú https://youtu.be/o6xGqi5itxs?si=LKeHXQb7RdEjF0Gh Thank you, Kate!!

TIL rice beer!

If a good Japanese beer (Yona Yona or similar) isn't available and I'm forced to settle for one of the big "beer" companies' swill, I always choose Kirin as it's the only of the big "beers" that doesn't list corn starch in its ingredients.

As anyone who‚Äôs been pushed into a HEDGEROW in a single track road with an oncoming car will know, another apt 15 letter phrase is:
OW! OW! OW! HAWTHORNS!

Great puzzle, really funny, perfect theme and beautifully clued and executed. 10/10 right George?

Anyone here ever read Geoffrey Household's "Rogue Male" (1938)? It's an adventure novel where much of the action takes place in Dorset, known for its great hedgerows. In the book the hero has uncovered a plot by mysterious agents of a totalitarian state, who begin zeroing in on him in the Dorset countryside. He burrows into a hedgerow and essentially becomes a part of its complex micro-life and its various wild denizens and inhabitants. The denouement is unputdownable. And it makes one want to see the great hedgerows and explore them. I've seen some in Ireland that are so alive, vital, verdant yes, but also ancient and mythic, that approaching them felt like entering the realm of another older order, where humans were no longer dominant, like those kids tumbling through the wardrobe into Narnia.
If there's a bustle in your hedgerow, don't be alarmed now.

Oh, trying not to laugh. We AUSSIEs dont "ask" Fair Dinkum. If anything it's the answer, not the question, a statement even. 
Is that true? Fair dinkum it is!
33d/33a are bad clues canadians say zed
Thank you, Kate Hawkins, for this entertaining puzzle. I thought it was a bit challenging for a Tuesday but I nevertheless enjoyed it.
A delightful romp through the colorful prevarications of the English language. No need to hedge my thanks to Kate for constructing such an enjoyable puzzle!

Extreme nitpick - but as a former beer nerd and one time home brewer - ‚Äúa crispy lager‚Äù or ‚Äúa bright lager‚Äù would‚Äôve been more appropriate for a Pilsner, a nod to its Czech origins and the noble Saaz hops. 
But as I said, extreme nitpicking here.

Just another solver at work . . .

Wondering how to spell Z?
In a British head, you call it zed please
It was a strange cross, it made me nervous
It took me in with an oceanic preface
And I said

Did you solve with a time down under?
Frowhatitsworth it's just a number.
Was your streak, your streak just put asunder?
You better run, manana may be tougher!

Buying beer from a man in Brussels
He was six-foot-four and full of muscle
I said, "Do you serva-a ricebeer here?"
He just smiled and gave me a dry pilsner
And he said

I've defused your puzzle blunders
When glitches jab you'd wahwah and thunder.
Onlyathougthbut would you concur?
Oreos are the areolas of crosswords.

My Diary of a Crossword Fiend review: https://crosswordfiend.com/2025/12/08/tuesday-december-9-2025/#comment-565579 For anyone not familiar with with Diary of a Crossword Fiend, we review about a half-dozen puzzles each day, including the NYT, Los Angeles Times and Wall Street Journal. It's a good way to lear about some good puzzles that you might otherwise have missed.

AAH, we‚Äôre GAGA over this puzzle! Kate has once again LANDED a 10/10. AS FAR AS I CAN TELL, this is just about the cleverest theme ever. Put all those long hedgy phrases together and it ADDS up to PURE fun. We could live on a DIET of Kate‚Äôs puzzles. They‚Äôre our favorite cup of TEA. Please FIRE up your creative engine and START creating more Kate! We can‚Äôt do them OFTEN enough!!

id rather the long theme crosses be among the most difficult rather than the easiest pars on the course but the devilish 33A/D bunker made up for it.
a fine tuesday round.

That new thriller about gardening? I was on the hedge of my seat!

(What a plot!)
Good puzzle, FWIW.
What a great Tuesday puzzle. I was confounded by ZEE and ZED, missing the Z and thinking for sure I must have the crosses wrong. Still under average even with a couple of typos.

Completed this very enjoyable puzzle in good time while procrastinating studying for law school exams. Congrats - and my thanks- to Kate on a wonderful puzzle that transported me out of Business Organizations and into a HEDGE maze for a couple of minutes!

This was fun, like unwrapping packages to reveal the prizes inside.  Not too challenging for a Tuesday and not at all dull, a tough combination to cobble together for any day.

Thanks, Kate!

I personally found this way too hard for this time in the week, mostly because of the multiple proper names. I was very close to looking stuff up - on Tuesday!

Also, two of my least favorite style of clues - one referencing the other, with little indication of what's actually meant - crossed...

There also was a directional clue. Gah. That's just such blatant filler it always detracts from my enjoyment of a puzzle (especially when, like today, I haven't even heard of one of the cities).

Microsoft keeps pushing its apps and services on me in Windows. It will sometimes take me against my will to its MSN portal. I don't know about the US but in Poland it consists fully of clickbait of the worst, most p¬Æimiti‚úì‚Ç¨ kind. I detest it, and I hated to be reminded of it by the puzzle.

Finally, Schr√∂dinger's AhH/AAH also made an appearance, the final nail in the coffin of my solving enjoyment.

Was it a bad puzzle? Even I can see it was not, but I still did not personally like it.
Just one man‚Äôs opinion, but I loved this puzzle
"Fair dinkum" is a response, not a question, something like "fair enough". You'd never really ask someone "fair dinkum?" similar to how you wouldn't ask "fair enough?"
I'm not an expert, but IMHO this seems to be a very satisfying Tuesday puzzle.
Loved it except for THA ‚Ä¶ I don‚Äôt speak Spanish so  THAt really messed me up.

Argggh, foiled!!. I was trying my ‚Äúdon‚Äôt use the down clues‚Äù challenge and I almost managed it. I got stuck on PADRE - I had ‚ÄúSabre‚Äù which seemed perfect if not for the British spelling, and I tried ‚ÄúShark‚Äù which looked likely but gave an improbable ‚Äúkpa‚Äù as the down fill that definitely looked likely to be EPA or ‚Äúspa‚Äù but not ‚Äúkpa‚Äù. I was overly sure of ‚ÄúB-list‚Äù and hadn‚Äôt thought as far as DLIST. 

Nice puzzle! But tantalizing to literally clear all the hedges, only to fall at the last hurdle‚Ä¶
Am I the only person who‚Äôs bothered by 21 across? Santa Cruz is absolutely, unequivocally, southwest of San Fransisco. Am I missing something?
Hey, did anyone else have their streak wiped?  Not happy!

I know I need to get over it (WAH WAH WAH) but I really dislike the clue "On a regular basis" for OFTEN. :S 

Fun puzzle though üòÉ
Good puzzle, but I was thrown by Zee/Zed. I mean I understand the Zee/Zed pronunciation thing, but it wasn‚Äôt/isn‚Äôt obvious to me as a clue‚Ä¶
Lovely puzzle, and I was so happy to see a St. Louis reference (13D).  If only the Cards could make me as happy!

A crunchy Tuesday, but enjoyable. The ZED/ZEE crossing stumped me for a while, but raised a chuckle when I finally got it.

Today in Pedants Corner; THA is not a word. I don‚Äôt care if rappers use it, or even if it‚Äôs in the dictionary. Who uses THA as a legitimate alternative to The?  Here endeth today‚Äôs rant.
Enjoyed the puzzle but have to really squint to see the theme even after reading about.

I for, one, don't have to cross the Atlantic, just the Detroit River.
(or, for that matter, just turn and face the other end of the living room sofa.)

Four grid spanning themers, three of which are debuts and still managing to deliver an interesting Tuesday level puzzle?

Well done, Kate.

Lovely crossword.
The crossers solved everything I didn't know, except the zed. Just a bit tougher than usual. I have no idea what an "animated meme loop" is but I really don't care, although I'll try to remember it.

Thank you!

There, for a bit, I was thinking "verdant privacy features" were FIG LEAVES -- and it fit!






Et tu, emu.

Zee/Zed tripped me up.  I tried using a rebus even though it‚Äôs Tuesday to make it Sea/Bed since that‚Äôs what‚Äôs across the Atlantic.  : )

Fun puzzle!

At our house, hedgerows are big arguments. Like:‚ÄùPlease just decide!! Either he loves you, or he loves you not - stop wavering! And go cut down some of those daisies, they‚Äôre blocking my view of the dinkum patch!‚Äù

And that is absolutely, 100% true.

This is one of those days where I pity the long-time solvers who skip early week puzzles.  What a gem this is on many levels.

The empty grid itself is calming to look at, IMO, making for a subtle-yet-lovely intro to the puzzle. 

The theme answers, IMO, roll easily off the tongue, and it‚Äôs amazing that Kate found four at exactly 15 letters.  They also pop with freshness ‚Äì as three of them are NYT debuts, and the fourth has appeared in the Times puzzle but twice before.  

It‚Äôs also amazing that the grid is filled as cleanly as it is, given the sky-high 69 theme squares.

Talk about LANDED ‚Äì that revealer HEDGEROWS!  How perfect is that?  Descriptive, punny, and I never saw it coming.  ‚ÄúOh brava!‚Äù I shouted inwardly upon filling it in.

Then there was the sweet serendipity of LANDED, as a joke, crossed by a backward HAW HAW.

I came to the box today favorably disposed, Kate, because your puzzles exude quality.  Once again, you delivered.  Thank you!

I'm amused by the number of commenters complaining about THA.

I look forward to the day when that "word" gets clued as "Charlemagne ____ God".  
Oh, what a discussion we'll have then!
Very enjoyable Tuesday puzzle, with a cute theme and solid fill. Never used the theme/revealer while solving, but upon review I felt they paired quite well. Nice puzzle!

I'm surprised that no one--not even @Lewis, who loves parallelisms--has mentioned TuLiPs, with their six PeTaLs (In fact, only three are technically PeTaLs, the other three being sePaLs--thus the coinage of the term "TePaL.")

(Not to be confused with the ST:E character T'Pol.)

Four 15-letter entries plus a revealer, with very decent fill and an entertaining theme. I'm truly impressed.

But don't quote me on that.

Always happy to see another Katie Hawkins day and wasn't disappointed. Good long workout for me, but just lots of nice moments when I worked things out from the crosses. 

One answer history search today was inspired by HEDGEROWS. 

BUSTARD -  once - in  a pre-Shortz puzzle.

BUSTARDS - twice - also in pre-Shortz puzzles.

Some of you will get that. I'll put my puzzle find in a reply. 

....

I don‚Äôt have to HEDGE today to say I enjoyed this puzzle and the theme. I got ZEE and ZED pretty quickly, but I can see why you might not like self referential clues that cross like this (but NOT because Canada just happens to say ZED as well Britain). I liked the reminder that some EMERITI are women and the nod to Oh, MARY. I didn‚Äôt see it but I heard wonderful things about it, and had the pleasure of meeting Bianca Leigh who played the chaperone and seeing her perform in person. She is a wonderful actress and person in general.
Merely my opinion(15 letters), but this was a fun theme with a great revealer.
LOL ‚ÄúDont make me angry‚Äîyou wouldn‚Äôt like me when I‚Äôm angry‚Ä¶‚Äù https://m.youtube.com/watch?v=dHSxQ2RRD9o
When I was uneducated in across the Atlantic spelling, I checked into a London hotel and gave the desk clerk my name. He asked if my last name started with ZED and I replied " No, it starts with ZEE"

This one had two things I strongly dislike in crossword puzzles: 1) a ‚Äúsound‚Äù answer (37D) - too subjective, though this one was thankfully fairly straightforward, and 2) whatever you call the ZEE/ZED pairing at 33A/D that has no real clue. Shouldn‚Äôt one of the clues be [Last letter of the alphabet]? Despite those, I did enjoy this puzzle‚Äôs theme. So clever!

Hmmm....seems to me there are quite a few countries across the Atlantic. ü§îüòÇ
Fun puzzle. Thanks!

Really loved this one. I didn‚Äôt find the theme a hindrance or a necessity for solving the puzzle but rather a fun addition, exactly what I want them to be. The clues were tricky but largely fair, with a wide range of subjects, but nothing too obscure. 

I will echo others who ask that onomatopoetic words be left out of these puzzles as there isn‚Äôt a standardized spelling for them in several instances. Some may like that level of obfuscation, but I find it a bit too loosey-goosey, if you will, and crossing two of them together was a bit cruel.

I did really, really hate the ZEE/ZED clue and found it, on its own, to be nearly impossible to get. That definitely could have been omitted. 

Overall a fun puzzle! Happy Tuesday!
@Sam, once again a pun-perfect picture and caption, followed by an uber-entertaining writeup.  We are lucky and privileged to have you.
Great puzz! ‚ÄúIf there‚Äôs a bustle in your HEDGEROW don‚Äôt be alarmed now!‚Äù - Robert Plant
As far as I can tell, ‚Äòbedamn‚Äô is a quint term for putting a curse on someone, rather than for swearing

Asahi Super Dry sounds like an extremely niche deodorant. 

"When you don't want your frat bros to know you were in detox."

My comment got emu'd.
I got the puzzle, but many of the Comments (because I went ahead and read all the way down) were opaque (for me, anyway) and detracted from the puzzle itself.

WAHWAH

Actually, "wah-wah" is the term for a type of mute, and can be used on various brass instruments--trumpet, trombone, etc. I don't find them inherently sad, although a search for [Trombone Wah-wah Mute] on YouTube appears to disagree with me. Here's two clips--both from Gershwin--which show them in action (and when is "Summertime" sad?): https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=E3h-iH4O_b0 https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=cwN0VplOoy8&list=RDcwN0VplOoy8&start_radio=1 (wah-wah mute at 1:40)

I love the cute and imaginative HEDGEROWS double meaning wordplay.  And finding four (4!) grid-spanning 15 letter answers to so neatly fit the theme -- well, that's a real coup!

A lively, breezy puzzle that makes for a splendid Tuesday outing.
Great puzzle!

Took our Lewis' advice and deliberately avoided the reveal answer which was a real treat when it finally filled in.  Not my last fill though:  Had to run the alphabet at the 33* square and got all the way up to "emm" before catching the ZEE.  Nice one and thanks. 

*(Too early for a Rolling Rock?)

Mmm, waffles for breakfast.

The clue for 11D needs to decide whether it is singular or plural. Professor/retirees? EMERITi held me up for a while. Apart from that, Mrs Lincoln, how was the play?

One more puzzle find. A Sunday from April 13, 2008 by Cathy Millhauser with the title: "How Insulting!" Some theme clues and answers: "Foul weather condition?" DISGUSTINGWINDS "Some moralizing about getting off a balance beam?"" SERMONONTHEDISMOUNT "Sophistication of clubs like Sam's and BJ's?" DISCOUNTERCULTURE "Her Royal Daunter?" DISMAYQUEEN "Coleslaw-loving children?" CABBAGEDISPATCHKIDS "Find chewing gum under a desk, perhaps?" DUCKANDDISCOVER Here's that link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=4/13/2008&g=88&d=A ....
This was a fun one. I was stuck on 33A/33D until I went through the alphabet letter-by-letter.

On the 33A / 33D

People in the USA say "zee"

English-speakers everywhere else -- UK, but also Canada, Australia, NZ, India, Singapore, Nigeria -- say "zed"
I might be confused here but what indicates anything related to the letter Z for 33A/33D? I got it simply by plugging in every letter at the end, but am I missing something?

Thank you, Kate, for a very fine Tuesday filled with a mix of clever clues and a fun theme. I especially liked seeing Oh MARY! featured. My husband and I saw it on Broadway this past June for Cole Escola's final performance and, FOR WHAT IT'S WORTH, what an absolute treat it was!

Happy Tuesday, everyone!
Enjoyed it except for 33A/D which I got by brute-forcing. And yes, I understood the answer but still don't like the clues for it.
Very nice puzzle, sadly tainted by ‚Äòzed/zee‚Äô.
Is ZED part of the Metric System? (Asking for a friend.)

This one really tickled my fancy.  I do love a good pun and HEDGE ROWS was that.

My last empty cell was - you guessed it - the first letter of 33A/33D.

My favorite moment in the whole puzzle was when the lightbulb went off.

Sure, I was working my way through the alphabet but then, I hadnt even gotten to E yet when it came to me.

great theme, some good to great clues.  A totally solid puzzle.

If there's a bustle in your hedgerow, don't be alarmed now
It's just a spring clean for the May queen
BOOOOOO circularly referencing clues like 33A/D BOOOOOOOOOOOO

Thoroughly enjoyed this puzzle and it filled in pretty quickly for me but add me to the ones confused on 33A/D. I don‚Äôt understand how the clue led you to that. I‚Äôm a very new solver so perhaps I am missing something??
No catching Zzzzzs on this one...fun Tuesday, Kate!  Grazie!!
I didn't really care for 33A/D. Unless I'm wrong, isn't an axis supposed to be an alternate clue (viz. if you don't get one, you'll get the other type thing)? The 33s tripped me up here...
I thought it humorous that ZZ Top is called Zed Zed Top ‚Äúacross the Atlantic‚Äù.
Wonderful. Doesn‚Äôt belong on Tuesday, though.

Lots of fun on a Tuesday üòÑ
I understand why some folks were stumped by the ZEE/ ZED crossing and I‚Äôll admit that I didn‚Äôt see it right away . . . the Z was my last letter to pop in. Then the light bulb came on üí°üòÑ
My fastest Tuesday solve yet! Loved it, thanks Kate.
No problem zee & zed, but ‚Äúat tune‚Äù? UGH  Not really sure this wouldn‚Äôt be better as an easy Wednesday.
There are so many obscure clues and answers in this puzzle. This was more frustrating than fun. Not a fan.

Now that was a fun Tuesday!  Four grid spanners in one puzzle, a new animal to learn about, a new show to check out, and some funny, funny clues that made me laugh out loud.  I thoroughly enjoyed Kate's puzzle and had a good time figuring out the challenging clues that were mixed in with the rest of the entirely doable fill.  Thanks for the fun Tuesday, Kate!

Late puzzle find - particularly appropriate for today. A Sunday from October 23, 1988 by John Greenman. Clues and answers: "EL" CITYRAILWAY "GEE" 1000DOLLARS "BEE" WASPSCOUSIN "EX" FORMERSPOUSE "ESS" CURVEINAROAD "VEE" VICTORYSIGN "TEE" LINKSDEVICE ZEE "ZEDINLONDON" And there were more. Here's that link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/PS?date=10/23/1988&g=124&d=A ....

Maybe there should be 2 separate forums. One for those who enjoy a challenge and may not get everything on the first go through and another for the nitpicking. It‚Äôs a crossword puzzle for goodness sakes. Yes this was a bit more challenging for a Tuesday to some and there are those who aced it. But you can say that about every crossword ever created.

Overall I enjoyed this puzzle. My only complaint, and I‚Äôm guessing many others had the same, was the zee/zed clue. I actually think this is a clever dual clue but ‚Äúacross the Atlantic‚Äù is nonsensical. How are you supposed to get Zee/Zed from that? There has got to be better wording than that
The pie thrower in the photo was none other than Adam Jones, one of my all-time favorite Orioles!
didn‚Äôt get a bit of it but the stuff i did get was enough to fill in the blanks elsewhere. enjoyable!
I liked the ZEE(33A) ZED(33D) corner‚Ä¶ and learned that across the pond‚Ä¶ Liberia is a ZEE country.  As is the Philippines!

One more late puzzle find; I'll re-post this tomorrow. A Thursday from February 12, 1998 by Richard Silvestri. Three theme clues and answers: "Opposition?" FOLLOWINGPHOTO "Exposition?" BEFOREWYEANDZEE "Deposition?" BETWEENLAANDDA Here's that link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=2/12/1998&g=37&d=A ....

Okay, I failed to finish the puzzle because of the first letter of 33A and 33D.   Well, guess what?  Another reason we'll never be the "51st state" is because WE SAY "ZED" TOO!  And we ain't across the Atlantic!   A terrible clue and totally unfair to Canadians.  Thought you blue-state New Yorkers respected us . . .

I quite enjoyed this one! I have nothing of note to say, just jumping in to mention that this was pleasant in case the constructor is reading these comments.

Happy Tuesday everyone

@Michael Weiland et al

And then "bustards?"??  Extinct birds..large ones...where?

I'm not being prissy; I just don't see how any of this relates to the puzzle, adds to the fun, or makes real sense.  WAHWAH.

@Jo I'm not an Aussie, but am visiting there at the moment (dateline & time zones are making it a challenge to keep my streak going!) and came here to make the same point. It's an expression, but not a question. To quote Merriam-Webster: slang, Australia : unquestionably good or genuine : excellent ‚Äîoften used as a general expression of approval these cigars are fair dinkum ‚ÄúFair dinkum.‚Äù Merriam-Webster.com Dictionary, Merriam-Webster, https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/fair%20dinkum.accessed 9 Dec. 2025.

@elysia
So this is where I really really struggle to respond to comments like this in a respectful, non condescending manner. If you had only said ‚Äúinterestingly enough, Canadians also say Zed and they are across the Atlantic from England too and not across the Atlantic from the US‚Äù‚Äî and then I could have just said ‚Äúwow, I don‚Äôt know that, thanks for teaching me something (well I knew it but still it‚Äôs interesting info).
But no you had to start with ‚Äúit‚Äôs a bad clue‚Äù which really makes me want to say something sarcastic like ‚Äúwow you are right it you travel at the same latitude from England you hit Canada so that can‚Äôt be right (although you might hit part of Maine, or you might travel across the Great Circle), or I might say Thank God you let us know that, but at least they didn‚Äôt say across the pond because you know the Atlantic is not a pond it‚Äôs an ocean!!!
But I won‚Äôt, I‚Äôll just say, no I don‚Äôt think it‚Äôs a bad clue because the US is across the Atlantic from Britain, it‚Äôs just an expression, and I don‚Äôt think this clue was very misleading or inaccurate.
There, I held it in. Thanks for pointing it out but I respectfully disagree.

@Times Rita
I'm not fond of THA in a get-off-my-lawn-you-kids kind of way. I know, I am less and less young.
But I can defend SPITBALLs, repellent though they are in origin. OED online gives the date of first use of the verb as 1955. (The noun goes back to the 1840s or even earlier.) Apparently, the practice of using spit to shine shoes gave rise to the first spit balls. There's also a baseball usage and a schoolkid's weapon.
The usage here derives from the latest meaning, a kid's game of spitting balls against a wall to see if they stick.
Off to wash my hands.

@HW "or even if it‚Äôs in the dictionary"

Welp! you have certainly sent me down the Pedants Rabbit Hole this morning!

I have five on-line dictionaries bookmarked, 'cause, well, I'm a nurd: OED, M-W, Green's Dictionary of Slang, and yes, Wiktionary.org; as well as the Middle English Compendium (hosted by the University of Michigan, 'cause everyone in Ann Arbor speaks likes Chaucer).

Of those five, "tha" does not appear in M-W at all, nor, surprisingly, GDS, at least as a headword. Unsurpringly, it does appear in Wiktionary, in it's "rap usage."

Now, under the headword "the," the OED lists dozens of forms, historical and dialectical, with hundreds of citations, and those include the form "tha." Now, many of the historical forms used the spelling "√æa," with the thorn, but let's just look at the the ones with "th." 

Back when English was still an inflected language, "tha" appears as a form in certain genders and cases--feminine accusative, for one, as in "ic luvie tha  sangestre Jennifere Lopez." I write this, as the OED *lists* "tha" as a spelling, but doesn't offer  any citation.

However, as  generalized (non-inflected) Modern English form, the ONLY example the OED offers is as a Northern Irish dialectical variant; and as a citation offers a quote from a leaflet published by the Health Promotion Agency for Northern Ireland: "Gin yersel or anither bodie in tha hoose is no weel."

So clearly, the Wise Clerks of Oxenford don't listen to American rap.

(Boy, that was fun!)

If I had to choose a single adjective, I'd pick 'wistful'. The opening is a counterfactual recitation of longings; nobody's rich or living easy. The middle (One of these mornin's...) is an imagined, probably unattainable future. The ending (But till that mornin') is again counterfactual. The song is a moment's ease in a hard life.

Steve,
Do you remember the first time you ran into a crossword clue (or clue pair) that seemed to make no sense until you filled in some of the answer(s) from crosses? I don't, and I doubt you do either. But I'm sure it threw both of us. Now we don't give it a second thought. We've got quite a few people here for whom this is the first time.

@D

The clues didn't give the solver anything?  How about that they started with a common letter, and were each a different name for the same thing, depending on which side of the Atlantic you are on?

Additionally:

The crosses seemed fair, and if you had -EE and -ED, the Z should have been obvious.

Specifically:

The words "extra dry" and "lager" in 8D virtually assured that it would be some kind of BEER. 

25D is a word which, in its various forms, has appeared hundreds of times in the NYT puzzles, and what's more, is a common anatomical term.

41A's clue, [Historical] is an untricky synonym for OLD.  If you didn't have it straight away, you should easily have been able to get the L from GLITCHES, clued super easy.  

And 35A is the revealer.  Several of its crosses, like RESUME, PANDORA and MSN, seemed super easy.

Many people thought the clues were confusing, but I didn't find them to be so.  They  clearly meant that each word is the other's counterpart on other side of the Atlantic.

Hope this helps!

@Barry Ancona

Yes, but as you're fond of saying, thankfully, it's a **crossword** puzzle.

I never expect to get everything right off the bat.  Sometimes, no matter how good I become, I'll never know the answer without the crosses.  Mauna ___, anyone?

As you have said, it's puzzling how many people are upset when they are puzzled by a puzzle.

What is also puzzling is that some of these same people think that if they couldn't figure it out, the clue was bad.

@Steve L
I would have thought that the ZED/ZEE divergence would be common knowledge to crossword solvers. "End of a series in Shropshire" seems like a clue I've seen before.

Steve,
Perhaps people who start solving on a phone are more likely to expect every clue to lead directly to an answer and less likely to (want to) consider crosses? We started solving on paper, so we always saw the grid while reading clues. And, of course, if we thought a clue was bad, we had no audience for our complaint.

@Barry Ancona

I may have thought a clue was obscure, hard to figure out or vague, but I never thought a clue was bad unless I had a great deal of experience in a subject, and thought the clue was inaccurate.

It just seems a lot of newbies are quick to jump on the bad-wagon just because they're not ready to handle something.

If they want to be very good at something super fast, they should concentrate on Wordle.

Seriously.

@Steve L And what I‚Äôm telling you, what several here are telling you but you refuse to listen or believe them, is that, when left with -ED and -EE, the remaining letter was not intuitively drawn through the clue alone, thus leading them to run the alphabet. Anything else still confusing you?

OK, go back to my original comment.  Here it is in its entirety:

I am gobsmacked, simply gobsmacked at how many people are complaining about  33A/D.  It seemed very ordinary a combination to me, with gentle crosses to enable the solver.
____

To paraphrase:  I'm surprised so many people are complaining about ZEE/ZED, because I didn't find anything odd about it, and the crosses were gentle.

So you asked for more detail.

Those were my experiences.

I will further elaborate that I didn't fill the answers in immediately because I wasn't certain what I was suspecting was right, which is a good tactic unless you have no other choice than to just guess things until something sticks.

Once I got the EE and the ED, the answer was obvious to me.  Had it not been obvious at that point, I'd have gone through the alphabet mentally, and gotten to "finding the thing I was looking for in the last place I looked."

This is a standard crossword strategy, and even the most experienced solvers do this.

We don't consider it a big deal if in the end, the crossings were fair, and there weren't two equally valid choices (unless that was intentional; see "Schrodinger puzzle.")

Bottom line:  You relate your experience, the others their experience, and I relate mine.

I was just surprised so many people were hung up in that spot.  Or maybe that they felt they had to complain about it. (See my reply to Barry.)

@Debbie R First - welcome! Second - it was a bad clue that didn‚Äôt lead you to that answer on its own. The puzzles have those once in a while.

Debbie,
Sometimes in crosswords you need to use the crossing words to start to fill in answers before the clues for those answers begin to make sense. This was such a case (or pair of cases). I didn't know what the clues meant until I had a few of the letters from crosses. Newer solvers may not have encountered this before; it's not uncommon. Now that you've been alerted to it, the next time it happens you'll be all set.

@Debbie R

Before long, you'll be knocking clue/answers like that out of the park with ease.

A lot of cross word solving is just having seen a lot of crosswords.  Even the dread fill like ONO and OREO, mystifying at first (depending on the cluing), becomes second nature in a short while.

And every one of those provides valuable information for the crosses.

Keep at it!  It gets better and better, though not necessarily monotonically.
